messages: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:34): I just don't understand how some people can blatantly ignore evidence and make bogus claims about XHTML2's compatibility
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:34): I think it's a matter of having different criteria for compatibility
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:36): the major criteria is whether or not a) legacy markup will still work in future UAs, and b) future markup will degrade gracefully in legacy UAs
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:36): XHTML2 doesn't fit either of those
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:36): that's your major criteria, sure
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:36): what else is there?
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:38): well, Rob Burns seems very concerned with the semantics of the elements and attributes... to him, that's pretty important... I thought he'd made that clear
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:38): I'm not too concerned either way, myself
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:39): I have lots of opinions on it, but none of them have resolved to a single path
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:39): yeah, but I haven't seen him describe any specific semantic incompatibilities (though, perhaps I missed it if he did)
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:42): anyway, this isn't actually a technical issue, but a political one
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:42): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Robert Burns has pretty clearly announced that he has different criteria for what constitutes "namespace integrity"
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:42): both groups want control of the XHTML "brand"
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:42): I actually don't care about the brand, but the namespace URI is not negotiable
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:43): (the one that HTML5 will use, that is; don't really care what XHTML2 does)
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:43): well, you've actually argued about the name (the brand) before
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:43): I also don't think we have any reason to try to be compatible with XHTML2
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:44): again, it's my opinion that this isn't a technical argument per se
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:44): the namespace URI argument has technical impact
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:44): even if it's being fought with technical terms
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:44): yeah, but not as clear-cut as all that
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:44): b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424: the namespace issue is entirely technical
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:45): the branding issue is more political
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:45): I think it's part and parcel
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:45): in what way is the namespace issue political?
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:45): the technical aspect of the ns issue is just a battle in the war of the brand, as far as I can see
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:46): it's pretty clear-cut to me, HTML5 has to use the XHTML1 namespace to support existing XHTML1 content, which is a goal
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:46): on the XHTML2 side it is political and as far as I can tell dishonest
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:46): the idea that the XHTML2 spec has a different namespace but that's just a placeholder smells of revisionist history
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:47): I think the same change could be leveled at both sides
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:47): which is why I'm getting increasingly bored with it

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:47): yeah, the XHTML2 side hasen't put forth any technical argument for having the XHTML1 namespace, and have only been ignorant/dismissive of the technical arguments from the HTML5 side
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:48): including the feigned outrage
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:48): yeah, that's almost as much fun as being ostentatiously above-it-all
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:48): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220, I don't think the HTML5 side has any room to talk about being dismissive
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:49): b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424: care to elaborate?
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:49): nah, being ostentatiously above-it-all is much more fun, since you can laugh at both sides
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:49): its the only way I can keep calm about the whole thing
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:50): well, I'm not quite ready to put Robert Burns in the Dmitry Turin bucket
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:50): Dmitry is entertaining
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:51): so I try to actually engage
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:51): I think Burns aluded to having some sort of product... not sure it's a browser, or authoring tool, or what
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:52): I think Burns is being very straightforward
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:52): Dmitry is more annoying than entertaining for me
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:52): well, I can understand that
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:53): I've deliberately taken a step back to ease my blood pressure... otherwise, reading public-html is like having road-rage for me
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:53): I'm only getting involved in issues I think are important
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:53): yeah, that's probably a good idea
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:54): well, not exactly... a lot of it's important... but i'm only jumping in where I think the direction is going someplace I can't accept
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:54): I think I'm going to have to stay right out of XHTML2 discussions from now on
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:54): the rest of it, I figure will work itself out somehow
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:55): I think I will limit comments on XHTML2 to mentioning that XHTML2 is off-topic, should that seem necessary
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:56): well, is it?
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:56): I mean, the whole NS issue isn't settled... nor is the name issue
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:56): or did I miss something?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:58): b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424: IMHO, the name issue is settled in favour of calling it XHTML5 and ignoring the XHTML2 WG's objections, and the namespace issue is settled in favour of XHTML5 reusing the XHTML1 namespace, and letting the XHTML2 WG use whatever they like and ignoring them
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:58): a proposal to change the namespace wouldn't be off-topic, just ill-conceived
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (11:58): talking about compatibility with XHTML2 is off-topic
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:58): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I think that's an opinion, not a resolution
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (11:58): like I said, unless I missed something (which is very possible)

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:59): well, it's resolved as far has the HTMLWG is concerned.  Let the XHTML2 WG come up with whatever resolution they like for themselves, as long as their resolution doesn't affect us.
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (12:00): was there a formal resolution?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:00): not a formal one
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (12:00): then it's not resolved
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:01): but there's no point, since there have been no solid technical arguments against that resolution
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:02): we didn't have an official group vote or anything
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:02): but also no one seems motivated enough to call for one

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:03): b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424: the MIME type and the namespace URI are not negotiable for the XML serialization of HTML5, but if those say "xhtml", not calling the thing "XHTML something" is silly
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:08): Philip`: is the zaynar.demon Philip Taylor you?
